description:
The thriving colonies of Zel'var are the destination for many adventurous souls who choose to leave the solar system and good old planet Earth seeking a new life and good fortune – but not all find what they are looking for. Many become disillusioned, discontent even, and turn to pirating the prosperous trade routes between the five planets, much to the regret of the colonies' leaders, who have great need of the trade income in order to advance technologies and create jobs for the newly-arrived colonists.

Colonies is a game of resource management in the far reaches of space in which the players compete to dominate in trade, politics and technological development. Each player controls the administration of a planet with access to a unique resource. In order to win you need to collect the most colonial credits by trading resources, upgrading your technologies, keeping your trade lanes free of pirates, and perhaps pushing the council's decisions in the right direction.

At the begining of each turn, players receive an income of their own resource. The council meets each turn to vote on how to handle an occurring event. The outcome can reward those willing to put in an effort or punish those who are not. Players may do well to form alliances in order to sway the vote in a favourable direction.

The resource income and the colonists that arrive each turn – sometimes in large numbers, sometimes in small – are used to make advances in five areas: Community, Military, Commerce, Influence and Industry. Following the council's vote, players take turns to either upgrade these areas or activate one of them to grant asylum to pirates in exchange for resources or hunt them for bounty, sell resources for Credits, make trade agreements more beneficial, or produce additional resources. When everyone has had three such actions, the players receive and pay resources according to the trade agreements, and any colonists that players have failed to employ turn to piracy, preventing players from getting income from their trade agreements next turn unless preemptive action is taken.

Colonies lasts ten turns, with players earning victory points (VPs) from colonial Credits and technology advances. In the end, the player with the most VPs wins.

Abstract two player game with a soccer theme. The player that scores more goals than the other after an agreed time wins.

Each player has a team consisting of 11 figures. The playing field consists of 83 spaces with connections between them. On each space there can only be one figure or the ball.

On each turn a player can kick the ball in a straight line if he has a player next to the ball and move one of his 11 figures one space. If a player cannot kick the ball he can move two figures one space each (or one figure twice).

There are some more rules like fouls, passing or kicking the ball over an opposing figure.

A dice and card game for two to four players. In your turn, you roll the dice and if you roll a total on one of your cards, you can discard it. If a player is dealt an "X-IT" card, it may be used as a wild card, i.e., 1 to 6. First to discard all their cards, wins. X-IT cards held by the losers, count as 6 points, other cards as at face value.

It was the age of gods and goddess. Zeus (King of the Gods), Poseidon (Lord of the Seas), and Hades (God of the Underworld) had agreed to separate the sky, the ocean, and the underworld. Athena, the Goddess of Wisdom, would take over the rest of the earth. But the Norse gods were displeased by the decision. They called warriors and disciples to take the world from the Greek gods. The gods atop Mt. Olympus also called their warriors to defend them. During this war of the gods, a mass of warriors died, and their souls were sealed in a jar.

And now they are waiting for you to release them.

In the deck-building game Kanzume Goddess, you will be one of the Gods of mythology. Each God in the game has its own special powers which players can use to their benefit. Players will purchase cards from the center of the table to add to their decks. They will use these cards to purchase more cards and to do battle with the other players. These cards can be used to damage other players, to gain more cards, to draw more cards from your deck, and to protect yourself from damage. The last player with energy left is the last God standing and the winner of the game.

Kanzume Goddess can be played as an individual match with 2-6 players or as a team match if you play with 4 or 6 players.

Think Trunk is the perfect group and party game.  Its unique game play allows for everyone to be involved on every turn.

There are 5 different categories on each card: Think It, Number It, Act It, Prefer It, and Wing It.  All 5 categories encompass and expand on current games on the market but are adapted for multi-player input without teams.

The object of the game is to be the first player to get to the end and a single round takes 20-30 minutes.

Objective: Be the first moving up to field 80
- moving by turns -
throw the die and move according rolled number; ending on a red marked space follow instructions.

Operational level wargame for the battle of Midway in World war 2 Pacific theater.
This game published with Japanese history and military magazine "Rekishi Gunzo" #114 the Twenty Anniversary Issue. And also published along with Tsushima.

Players control either Imperial Japanese fleet or United States fleet.
Each player choose and resolve one of seven actions alternately. The seven actions is search, deck work, air sortie, resolve of air raid, mission abort, repair and additional damage check.
Unlike many other games, the grid map and unit movement are not include in this game. The game is progress by the viewpoint of the fleet commander.

Winner is determined by the damage given to enemy fleet and airbase each other, but Japanese player must given at least 6 points of damage for Midway airbase.

Issue game of Wargame Japanese History #12.

Operational level wargame on Hogen and Heiji rebellions during Japanese Heian period.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HÅgen_Rebellion
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heiji_Rebellion
This game include two scenarios for each rebellion and two type campaigns for combined rebellions.
A "gunki" is a war story (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gunki_monogatari).
Kiyomori is a famous Heian period person.

The game map covers city of Kyoto for movement and combat. It also includes main part of Japan for reinforcement march.
Each unit represents a lord (daimyo) or samurai warriors (retainers). All units has a battle rating and belong to one of the four clans. The clan is affect for unit activation and special ability. Certain lords (daimyo) have also special abilities.

Players control one side of each rebellion. Most side contains more than one clan.
Each turn players determine active clan by die roll. Activated unit are flipped down at end of their activation. So each unit can only activate once per turn, but Fujiwara clan's special ability allows them to reactivate flip down units.

Winner is determined by several victory condition per scenario. For example, elimination of highest lord, occupation of important areas, etc.

This is a France-themed BrainBox game.

Description provided by the publisher: Do you know where Mont St Michel is? Or where Camembert comes from? BrainBox All Around France contains 53 beautifully-illustrated cards showing the very best France has to offer, and then some! The object of the game is to study a card for 10 seconds and then answer a question based on the roll of a die. If the question is answered correctly, the card is kept and the person with the most number of cards after 5 or 10 minutes is the winner. Made from a minimum of 70% recycled material, the BrainBox range is fabulous fun. Find out who the BrainBox is in your family – it may not be who you think it is!
Objective: Be the first moving up to field 100- moving by turn - throw the die and move according rolled number; ending on a marked space follow instructions.

From the rule sheet

Wake up your environmental Protection consciousness

The Nature is easy to learn and quick to play.  It's best for four or more players, though you can play with three people or more than five.  The game aims to help players developing the consciousness of environment protection through fun and enjoyment.

Object to the game:
The object is to get living animal cards as many as you can in each round.  Points score on the cards in player's "Zoo" card pile but minus points in the player's "Tomb" card pile.

Game play:
Player started with 5 cards.  Each round he can 1) play a card; 2) draw a card and discard a card into his "Tomb" card pile.

When every player has play one card, the round is over.  The greatest card of the latest colour will be the winner of that round.  The winner can collect all the cards and place them into his "Zoo" card pile.

Game end when the last card is drawn from the deck.

Terapia

It is composed of a quad-fold board, the rules are printed on the back side of the box, 6 pawns (black, orange, red, blue, green, yellow) and 600 question cards. Themed on medical science, all questions are about medical (but not psychological) affairs.

The game goal is to be the first to move your pawn along the complete circle on the board from your starting color rectangle to the same position. There is a single pile of cards in the center of the board. Rectangles and cards are identified with 3, 2 or 1 dots. The player at your right asks you the question on the upper card of the pile. You must give right answer to the card question to be able to advance a single rectangle or 3 or 2 if dots stated in your actual position match the current question card dots. That has a maximum of three consecutive advances. Then the turn goes to the player at your right. If you fail a question the pawn moved is the one belonging to the player who asked the question.

Objective: Be the first moving up to field 43 (round trip)
- moving by turns -
throw the die and move according rolled number; ending on any image follow instructions glued on cover inside.
remarks: game belongs to the series: "Scholz' künstlerische Spiele" with very nice graphics/images;
as usual - cute pewter figures

As with the other BrainBox games, the object of the game is to study a card for 10 seconds and then answer a question based on the roll of a die. If the question is answered correctly, the card is kept and the person with the most number of cards after 5 or 10 minutes is the winner.

This BrainBox, as the title suggests, is Boston-themed.

Objective: be the first to pass finish line (100)
 - acting by turn -
throw both dice (1d6 & 5-coloured+joker one):
colour defines the question card to draw 
number determines the question to answer and - if correct - spaces to move forward;
starting from a pink space (luck) you may double allowed distance;
starting from a risk space you must move back if answer is wrong;
the very last (coloured) spaces must be taken step by step (no jump), card to be drawn determined by colour (no die).

LOT is played on an orthogonal grid of 7x7 squares, with two players struggling to be first to create a line of three stacks of two pieces each in any direction (orthogonal or diagonal). LOT was born while researching the concept of a simple piece-removal game mechanism that made loops impossible, but at the same time, produced potentially long games in a very small playing area. (The name LOT comes from "Line Of Three" and also from "Lots Of Turns".

Players alternate turns, with the second player having the option of swapping colors after the first turn (pie rule). On a turn, a player does the following in order:

1. Lays out a thing on an empty space: Place a piece of your color on an empty space of the board.

2. Looks over that:  If at least one line of three or more pieces (not stacks) of your color in any direction (orthogonally or diagonally) has been created, then you must do the following in order:


    Choose one of the lines of three that have been created and remove two pieces, but leave one there.



    Add one level of tower, by adding another piece of yours to the single piece that you left in place during the previous step, thereby creating a stack.


If at the end of the turn at least one line of three (or more) stacks of the same color has been created, the line's owner triumphs. If the board fills up before this happens, the game ends in a draw.

Objective: score most winning points with your team after 5 rounds
 - acting by turn -
active player tries to explain a term by pantomime within 2 minutes - no talking/drawing/writing allowed; 
if successful (somtimes with deduction due to allowed prodedures) there will be a bonus question;

content: 396 cards - splitted into 9 sections, 2 boards "dactylology", 1 card case, Kartenhülle, 1 notepad, rules.
remarks: compareable with 'body talks'

The board game is based on the popular 1985-2000 and 2001-2002 German game show of the same name, for which in turn was adapted from the short-lived 1982-83 American Game Show Child's Play.

Heroes of Metro City is a deck-building card/board game in which each player represents a super-powered Hero of his own design who must stop their Archenemy's nefarious plan to destroy Metro City. Devastate your enemies with thousands of possibilities and choices for your character. The base game includes over twenty explosive Power cards and many iconic Energy Sources, and a randomized subset of these will be selected for each game. It's an exciting array of possibilities for your customized super-powered Hero.

Heroes of Metro City uses dynamic deck-building combined with unique Energy Source slots to create a power management mechanism (using your Hero Placard) that lets you decide which powers and abilities are most important for each turn. The Hero Placard also helps to guide you through the six phases of each turn.

To succeed, the Heroes must do battle with hordes of Minions, diabolical Villains, and the Archenemy who leads them! The more Energy and Powers a Hero develops, the closer he gets to defeating their Archenemy. The first player to defeat the Archenemy wins the game...unless the Archenemy destroys so much of Metro City that there's nothing left to save!

Through the Arabian Nights!Hunting for precious treasures, four princes race across the sky of the Arabian nights on their flying carpets. But watch out for the air pockets! The turbulent night skies can easily bring the princes off course. Who will be the most adept at avoiding the air pockets and be the first to collect all the treasures?


Four Princes find a bunch of magic flying carpets and start an adventurous race throughout the arabian night skies!

As a player you choose one of the Princes on carpets and set off for a quest of finding treasures: 
By choosing and rotating arrow cards you navigate your Prince across the tilted magnetic board and thus try to reach the cloud castles in which the different treasures can be found. But be careful: In some spaces you might encounter air pockets - your prince "falls": the token slides down the board! A new flight path must be planned.

The game provides high replayability, for the board can be tilted in four ways - four different layouts of possible air tracks!

As a player you can either just fly around, which enables even young players to take part, or you can try to spoil the other players' paths by pushing them out of your way - and onto the next air pocket.

Great fun for players of all ages!

Objective: be the first distributing your invitations and solving your quests
 - acting by turn -
draw your quest cards first;
throw the die - move fore- or backwards (if there isn't any obstacle like a garbage bin);
ending on a marked space perform required action in order to get rid of one of your quests/invitation card

Extra! Extra! is all about completing the front and back pages of a newspaper, with a mixture of stories of different sizes. The larger the story, the better. Players score bonus points for stories in their speciality, extra material, interviews, and headlines.

In the game, players collect news in six newsworthy subjects: home, world, business, politics, sport, and leisure. To do this, they place their reporters on the news they want to publish, but they can be outbid by other newspaper owners with bigger wallets. Copy and photo cuttings can be obtained from "the morgue"; more reporters can be hired; and news sold to raise capital.

Whoever completes his front and back pages first receives a bonus — but will that player have enough Circulation Points to win?

A game for three or more secret-keeping rule enforcers.

Each player gets a secret rule at the start of the game. All rules are in play – including the ones you don’t know. It’s up to the person who has the rule to enforce it or not. Your goal is to be the first player to accumulate 3 points. The best way to do this is by learning the secret rules of the game faster than the other players and taking tricks.

You Need:
A standard Poker deck (Jokers removed)
A Hidden Rules trigger deck (available on the game's website)
A Hidden Rules action deck (available on the game's website)
Paper and pencil to track scores (optional, but recommended)

The basic game is played in tricks. The dealer begins the first trick of the game; after that, each trick begins when the last player to take a trick takes the top card of the deck, places it face-up on the table, and announces its value. Starting with the player to his or her left, and proceeding clockwise, each player must play a card from his or her hand on the trick, calculate the sum of all cards in the trick, and announce the sum.

Card Values: 2 through 10 are worth their face value. Aces are worth 1 or 11 (declared when played). Jacks are worth 0 points, Queens are worth -2 points, and Kings are worth -4 points.

If the sum is less than 21, play continues normally. If you bring the sum to exactly 21, you take the trick. If you push the sum over 21, the player to your right takes the trick, for forcing you to exceed 21. When you take a trick, add one to your score, and gather the cards from the trick into a pile face-down in front of you. Once taken, the cards from a trick may not be looked at.

All hidden rules are also in play. Each combination of a trigger and an action is a rule. It’s up to you to enforce (or not) a rule that you know about. When you enforce a rule, you must give the person information to indicate in what way their action violated the rule. The information you provide must be more specific than the violation. If you violate a rule, take back the card you played (if applicable), lose a point, and your turn ends (if it’s your turn).

For example, trigger #13 says, “When you play a card that makes the total exactly zero…” and action #5 says, “…Name a Peanuts character that hasn’t been named previously this game before you announce the sum of the trick.” If I make the total 0 and don’t say anything, you can make me take back my card and say, “You didn’t say a name.” The next time I make the total 0, If I say, “Neil Armstrong,” you can correct me again and say, “Neil Armstrong isn’t fictional.”

The first player to end a round with 3 or more points more wins.

This game owes a lot to the children’s “folk game” Mao.

In Whizz Bing Bang, a quick card game for 3 to 6 players, players take turns reading the top card of the deck, with the word on that card dictating how gameplay will continue:


    Whizz: Game play continues in the same direction.
    Bing: Game play reverses direction.
    Bang: Game play continues in the same direction, but skips the next player.
    Boom: Everyone must slap and leave their hand on the Boom while saying "BOOM!".


Penalties for playing out of order, slapping the deck when no Boom was played, being last to hit the Boom card, playing too slowly, etc. are distributed in the form of tokens, with players starting with one face-down token for each sound: Whizz, Bing, Bang, Boom (ordered low to high). The player who is first to hit the Boom card gives a token to the player who hit it last, but in all other penalty situations, players must race to find the lowest face-down token they hold and give it to the penalized player face up; whoever does so first gives the token away while all other players keep theirs and reshuffle them. When one player gives his Boom token away, each player scores one point for each token he holds. When a player has scored 15 or more points, the game ends and the player with the fewest points wins.

Objective: score most winning points climbing up the hill (Drachenberg) with your team of 3 (coloured) meeples
 - moving by turn -
roll the die & make up your mind who of your team should move forward; up to your choice: step out, jump or kick out on your way to the top - collecting winning points by adding the position of all your meeples;  
game ends after one figure has reached the peak.

Objective: Find your (coloured) 2 (correspondent) slides (memory) and move your meeple upon to gather them; move further to your (coloured) target space ending the game.
 - acting/moving by turn -
Each player throws the die moving forward & uncovering 2 slides:
wrong colour ==> flip them again; right: try (during your following turns) finding the correspondent one. If lucky move upon and grasp it/them (but avoid stepping upon an - additional - quest card, which spoils your further movement).

In Tabaluga: Der Regenbogenschatz, the objective is to be the first to gather five coloured cards.

For setup, 35 cards (each with 3 different rainbow colours) are laid out on the table. The active player throws 3 dice (each with 6 different colours). Then, all players try to find the matching card. The first person to do so keeps it. But be aware! An already gathered card may be targeted in the next round.

A simple dice game where You must complete animals (rooster, dog, cow, pig). 5 dices are rolled, each die face shows one half of an animal - front or rear half. When two halves of the same animal are rolled the player is allowed to grab one of the 10 animal tiles from the middle of the table. If two matching halves are shown then 2 tiles, if none show then he cannot do anything. When no appropriate tiles are in stock a player can snatch one from another player. The game ends when only 1 animal tile is left in the stock. Player with most completed animals wins.

In Uchronia, you are the patriarch of a great Uchronian noble house, competing with the other houses that commit their wealth to building the city, enriching it with new constructions, and striving to win over the people.

In game terms, players start with six resource cards in hand, then each discard a card to the shared forum; each resource card shows the type of resource (with color-coded five resources in the game), an activity icon (with, for example, all yellow clay cards showing a pick), and an order (with yellow showing Production). Five building cards are placed face-up in the Great Works area and can be built by the players; any time a building is taken from this area, reveal another building card.

On a turn, you first move any card(s) played the previous turn to the forum, then you either Command or Plot. To Command, you play one card from your hand with the order you want to carry out or two identical cards, which allows you to take any order. The orders are:


    Production: Place one card from the forum into your stock. For each Production activity you have, take the action again.
    Exploration: Place one card from your hand into your stock. Repeat for each Exploration activity.
    Draconians: Show one card from your hand, then move one card of this type from the forum to your stock; in addition, each player who commanded in his previous turn must give you a card of the same type from his hand, if possible. For each Draconians activity you have, you can show one more card, which lets you claim more from the forum and possibly more from opponents.
    Trade: Transform one resource in your stock to an activity. Repeat for each Trade activity.
    Construction: Start a new building (by discarding a matching color resource from the forum) or transfer a resource from your stock to a building in progress. Repeat for each Construction activity.


When you complete a building, you gain its special ability for the remainder of the game. You can have only two activities, plus one more for each completed building you own. If you have more of a particular ability than anyone else, you claim the monopoly card for this activity, making each of these activities worth 1 victory point (VP) and allowing you to claim a matching resource whenever anyone completes a building of this color.

If you Plot instead of Command, you first copy one order showing in another player's area (if you have an activity of the same color), then you either draw until you have five cards or draw one card (if you already have at least five).

The game continues until one or more players hits a VP threshold (14-20 depending on the number of players). After completing the round (giving everyone the same number of turns), the player with the most VPs wins.

War Echoes is a 32mm tabletop miniature game, set among a science fiction background. War Echoes uses squad level skirmish combat tactics on an individual character driven system. Five different factions and alien races populate the landscape each with its own unique weapons, abilities and game play style. War Echoes utilizes d10 dice for rolling, with character stamina ratings based on a modifier system for everything from movement to combat.

Tutatis is a fantasy gaelic football game produced by Greebo Miniatures, an italian editor already known for its high quality fantasy miniatures. The game is set in the fantasy world of Triskearth, a brand new world utterly created by the designers of the game. Its history and geography, as well as the background for every race, are described in the first 150 pages of the rulebook. The remaining twenty pages describe the gaming rules, bringing to life a fast & furios game of tactic and bashing!

The game is played on a 11 x 16 squares field, each team can field on the pitch seven payers. Every team (are planned to be released nearly thirty teams) has its own rooster of players, each one with its stats (movement, strength, agility, constitution, ball play), skills and costs, including three different captains. The game time is divided in two halves each one made up of six turns for each player. Turns are played alternatively by each player, completing the action of a single player before passing to the next one. The aim of the game is to score more points (goals or kicks over the crossbar) than the opponent, and you can achieve this with a passing/dodging style or with a more brutal one. Someone could recognize a gameplay similar to other games concerning sports, but this is not a great flaw since Tutatis has it's peculiar flavor thanks to the rules of gaelic football (ie. not forward passage, soloing rule exc.) and to the characterization of each team.

Greebo miniatures has produced a prerelease box of the game (with rules still in beta) at the 2011 Lucca Comics & Games convention, and it was a sold out. That box contained a cardboard field, Italian rulebook, two Greebo's d6, a ball and two teams in 15mm (orcs and dwarves). Since then on Greebo's website have been published in English and in Italian the definitive set of rules and the roosters for the new teams, all available as free downloads. At the moment have been released three kinds of fields (irond peak, thornwell and standard), the miniatures of some mercenaries and nine teams: orcs, dwarves, evil puppets, necros, poffy and five different teams of thornwell (frogs, lizards, turtles, snakes and a mixed team). Greebo's team is working on the championship rules expected to be released as open beta in mid autumn 2012, as well as on a new edition of the game box. It's also on the desk the translation of the rules in french and spanish.

Object: To be the last player left in the game.
Contents: 36 cards

Before you begin, find 3 tokens (buttons, sweets etc.) for each player. These represent his 3 “lives" and when he has lost them he is out of the game. The pack consists of 4 sets of cards numbered from 1 to 9, which have the following order of importance from highest to lowest:
Farmer's Wife, Dog, Cat, Mouse. Therefore, the 3 of "Dog" beats the 3 of “Cat".

The dealer shuffles the pack and deals one card, face down, to each player. During the game you must try to avoid holding the lowest card. The first player to the dealer's left looks at his card.
He can either say "Stick" and keep it or exchange it for the card belonging to the next player on his left in the hope of getting a higher number and/or set. The next player does the same and so on until it is the dealer's turn. He can either “Stick" or exchange his card for the top one of the pack.
Then all players turn their cards face up and whoever holds the lowest one puts one token into the kitty.
If 2 players hold the same lowest number, the lower set loses. All players put their cards onto a discard pile. The next player becomes the dealer. When the pack has been played through once, pick up the discard pile, shuffle it and play on. Play continues until there is only one player left who wins all the tokens from the kitty.

A Modern Greek word game.

Info from the publisher's website:

You are given the definition of a word, its first letter and what kind of word it is. Find which word it is and beat your opponents while at the same time you are expanding your vocabulary.

Info from the publisher's website in Greek:
Îˆχεις τον ορισμÏŒ μιας λÎ­ξης, το αρχικÏŒ της και τι μÎ­ρος του λÏŒγου εÎ¯ναι. Βρες την, κÎ­ρδισε τους αντιπÎ¬λους σου, πλοÏτισε το λεξιλÏŒγιÏŒ σου.

Components (info from back of the box):
- Cards with 1800 Greek words
- Cards with 1200 foreign words
- 1 dice
- 6 player pieces
- 1 board
- 1 sheet or rules

A children's version of Î Î¿Î¹ÏŒÏ‚ Î Î¿Ï Î ÏŒÏ„Îµ Î“Î¹Î±Ï„Î¯?.

A Greek trivia game for primary school children, 2400 questions about Geography, History, Arts, Animals and Plants, Sports and Science. The players move around a board and try to reach the finish line first.

(An earlier edition seems to have 1500 questions, a newer one 2400.)

Greek description:
Η παιδικÎ® Î­κδοση του Î Î¿Î¹ÏŒÏ‚ Î Î¿Ï Î ÏŒÏ„Îµ Î“Î¹Î±Ï„Î¯?.

Îˆνα ελληνικÏŒ παιχνÎ¯δι για τους μικροÏς μας φÎ¯λους, με 2400 ερωτÎ®σεις ΓεωγραφÎ¯ας, ΙστορÎ¯ας, ΤÎ­χνης, ΖÏŽων και ΦυτÏŽν, ΑθλητισμοÏ και ΕπιστÎ®μης. Οι παÎ¯κτες κινοÏνται στο ταμπλÏŒ και προσπαθοÏν να φτÎ¬σουν πρÏŽτοι τον τερματισμÏŒ.

It is near dawn on April 6th, 1862. The first major clash of arms in the western theater of the American Civil War is about to commence!

In Clash of Wills: Shiloh 1862, you and your opponent each control one of the opposing armies. As the Confederate player, you open the battle with a devastating surprise attack on the Union camps around Shiloh church. If you can rout the disorganized blue coats and take Pittsburg Landing before reinforcements arrives, you can deal a potentially fatal blow to the invading Yankees. As the Union player you must survive the initial onslaught and hold back the advancing rebels on the first day of battle. Then, the next day, you can deploy your full forces to crush this latest threat to the survival of the United States. Whose will prevails?

—description from the publisher

A Hungarian football-themed trivia game. Players answer questions and move their player pieces on a board.

Components: 1 game board, 8 player pieces, 800 cards with 4800 questions, 1 die, game rules

Objective: be the first scoring as many goals as agreed (3 or more) 
 - acting simultaniously/ 2 players or 2 teams (red and blue) -
game board has to be prepared (each row - 6 in total - is filled up with 5 slides/different numbers)
ball must be moved (from the attacker) into the next closer row in direction of defender's keeper: attacker nominates 2 (of 11) meeples with hidden numbers ==> multiply both to move ball upon a matching slide/area; defender acts in a similar way; if successful (same result) defender becomes attacker; if not, attacker gets closer to the goal ==> additional turn (with less meeples on both sides).
Close enough to score? - use goal & keeper chips in a similar way.

Some 'R' Set is a trick-taking game that uses a unique deck of 28 cards. The card suits are fractions (ex. 0/0, 0/1, 1/1, 0/2, 1/2, 2/2, ..., 0/3,..., 0/4, ..., 0/,6, ... 6/6) with the mid-cards also being worth extra points.

Some 'R' Set is best played with partners as in Spades. The object is to bid on how many points you and your partner will take. There are 21 available points: 14 from the available tricks and 7 from the red cards. Bidding goes around the table once where the players bid for the two-card blind. High bid takes the blind and decides which suit (fraction set) will be trump.

As in many trick taking games, and if you make your hand, you get the points; if you do not, you are set, hence the name: Some "r" set.

In the 2020s, publisher The Levi Game Company marketed this item as Single Some 'R' Set to distinguish it from Double Some 'R' Set, which (as of 2025) it is marketing under the Some 'R' Set. Confusing, yes...

You are a Navy SEAL. You are trained to confront terrorists and insurgents. You deal with hidden explosives, snipers and other unknown dangers. In the darkness of the ocean's depths or the vastness of the merciless desert, you expect the unexpected. You're on a mission. You work as a dedicated team, relying on the skills of expert marksmen and suburb tacticians. Careful planning and precise timing improve odds of success, but unforeseen events could jeopardize the mission.

Hooyah: Navy Seals Card Game is a cooperative game in which 1 to 4 players assume the roles of Navy SEALS trying to complete a real-life-inspired Special Ops mission. You either win or lose as a group. To meet the rigorous requirements of the mission, you must collect all of the Skills and Equipment cards required for each Op. All phases of the mission must be completed without the loss of life and before time runs out.

The Realm of Agennul is an ever evolving board game where you control the fate of the characters and the future of the realms. Our goal is to create a fantasy world and outlet for participants to collaborate and decide how characters, realms, and the lore develop within the game.

Players receive two characters, which must work together to earn the patronage of cities within Agennul. During the game players must protect those cities from invading players who are also competing for the control of the Realm.

Use characters to navigate through the Realm and conquer cities to gain coin and control of Agennul. With the coin upgrade, increase your city's defenses by paying coin for a fortification or purchase equipment for your characters to increase their abilities. Engage in epic battles between players as ego's grow while the limited towns and cities are fought over. Be conniving and pay off players to avoid conflict in order to secure your advancement in the Realm.

The Realm of Agennul is very simplistic at its core but can develop into a complicated strategic game as power shifts around the table between players.

The first player to have control of the most cities as well as the patronage of the Hero's City of Anos, is anointed as The Hero of Agennul and Protector of the Realms.

The game has 2 tops with spinners, and 10 small wooden pins that look sort of like bowling pins. The box bottom has four wooden pegs affixed in the pattern of a square in the center of the box. The eight pins are setup, and then each player in turn spins his top. 5 points for knocking a pin down, 10 points for throwing it out of the box. 500 points wins the game.
Simple race game where each of fours players race to get their three pegs from start to home. Spinner will give values between 1 and 4 for each spin.

Damage Report is a modular, 2-6 player, simultaneous, real-time, co-operative game where the players take on the role of a starship crew faced with making split-second decisions to survive while in the midst of various catastrophes. Unlike many co-operative games, the simultaneous, real-time nature of the game helps prevent groupthink. This forces players to make decisions with minimal feedback and prevents one player from simply running the show. Your turn never ends, and is only limited to what you can accomplish in 15, 30, 45 or 60 second intervals.

Each player uses a timer to keep track of their time, moving the timer down a track based upon how long their turn interval is. In most scenarios, the turn interval is based upon the Life Support system status: the more damaged the system is, the less air the player has to "breathe", thus each turn is extended, as it takes more time to complete their actions.

The modular board pieces in Damage Report ensure a brand new experience with each game scenario. Each scenario has their own 'success' and 'failure' conditions. The Standard Edition of the game includes three scenarios, however a number of additional scenarios will available as expansions. This will include a 7-10 player expansion.

Traps is a marble shooting game where each player tries to shoot marbles into specific locations on a board. When opened the game box creates a ramp, and a "backstop." One the backstop are seven position which have a hinged flap that shuts when a marble is shot through the opening. from left to right the positions are numbered 1 to 7. The positions also have point values of 5, 15, 10, 25, 10, 15, and 5. Three games can be played on the board, Traps, Golf and Tournament Play. From the directions:

HOW TO PLAY TRAPS

Any number of players may compete. Each player in turn will roll or shoot an inning of four balls, scoring the points as they are made, the one first reaching a total of five hundred points becoming the winner of the game.

HOW TO PLAY GOLF

TRAPS now becomes a seven hole links. Drive for No. 1 hole: after holeing, recover ball, return trap to closed position and shoot for No. 2; continue for the entire course. Player making seven holes in fewest shots is declared the winner.

Tournmment - Twenty-Five Bird Event

Player will specify by small number (not one or seven) the Pigeon he expects to break; if succesful, 1 is scored and player shoots again, first designating the intended shot (not one or seven); if again succesful, another point is credited and the third shot may be either 1 or seven, but in no case may one or seven be called, unless the shooter has previously broken two consecutive birds other than one or seven. failure to break the bird designated, loses the players turn, which goes to each entrant in rotation; winner is the one who first breaks 25 birds.

Came with four (4) wooden "bean bag" discs, a target board (with holes marked 5 points, 10 points and 20 points) and a stick with which to prop up the target board.

Directions from top of box:

    Arrange the Game as shown in the Picture below. The players
   pitch in turns, the first one who scores 50 points wins the
   game.

   Manufactured by J. H. Singer 
   New York, U. S. A.

A simple race game with 17 spaces on the board. The spinner has 8 different positions. So this is a very simple spin and move game. There are 4 markers that come with the game.

Spinner positions:

     3 - Land
     3 - Take off or Fly
     1 - Fly
     1 - Bad weather go back to last city (ie lose a space)

A simple and short game for young children.
"Get as high as you can and get the gold. But watch out - if you climb high it's a long fall."
Players climb up the dragon by rolling dies, and try to get gold pieces from the dragon. But if they get to high they fall down and have to start over again. When all the gold have been delt, the player with the most pieces wins.

Two gangs of bikers meet in the desert and after drinking themselves silly decide that jousting on their motorbikes, using shotguns rather than lances, is a good idea.

A two player push your luck game. Each player has 11 cards, and each selects and plays one card from their hand simultaneously until one or both players plays the "BLAM" card, which ends the round.  The player playing the "BLAM" card scores for the cards they have already played this round. The game is played over four rounds.

From the rule book:
"Counting Town is an engaging, imaginative and colourful play set that invites the child to do something very special: learn while playing."

The rule book provides 12 games for children to play.  Each game is provided as a learning excercise for the children playing.  The games focus on the language and number concepts such as colours, distance, time, quantity, sequencing etc.

All 12 games follow the same sequence of play:
The teacher setups the board for play.
A background story is provided for the game.
The teacher poses questions to the children based on the board setup.
The children then take turns based on the directions of the teacher (i.e.  the teacher directs the children to move the parts around the board - the teacher then asks additional question to the children).

Gather your courage! The long-enjoyed peace of Yon has been disrupted by a ferocious and mean-spirited dragon — he's terrorizing the locals and eating their livestock without their permission! Fortunately, a few wannabe heroes (that's you!) have risen to the challenge of slaying the beast. Get yourself a brave companion, gather a powerful army, and enter the Dragon's Keep for cheese and country in Dragon Farkle!

To play, you gather an army of loyal soldiers or steal them from your opponents, hire suspicious-looking companions and gain allegedly useful items (most of which aren't even cursed), then fight that dragon you've heard so much about — or don't, if you hate winning...

Described as "the card-flipping, risk-taking game." This version is a card game whereas other Farkle games are typically dice games. The aim is to score 10,000 or more points (although with 6 or more players you can decide to play to 5,000 or 7,500 points).

There are 110 cards - 14 each of 1-6, 22 Farkles and 4 score summary cards. Each player is dealt one card BUT all players can play off anyone else's cards. The rest of the deck is placed in the middle of the table and each player takes it in turn to draw one card from the deck and place it in front of themself or another player. The goal is to create combinations that score (eg three 1s = 300 points, three 6s = 600 points, six of any number = 3,000 points and so on). If you create a winning combination you can either slide it to the center of the table for potential scoring or leave it where it is to try and build a bigger score. You can stop drawing at any time and score any cards you've placed in the center. However, if at any time you draw a Farkle card you MUST stop drawing, and any cards in the center can't be scored and become part of the face-up cards in front of you. You keep your Farkle card to one side and no other players may take it but you may use it to score later. Farkle cards are scored whenever their owner makes a successful scoring combination. The first player to 10,000 points (or the agreed total) wins!

The publisher places no limit on the number of players.
